remedi_style_dialogue_annotations.utterance_text: Hello, thank you for coming in today. I understand you’ve been experiencing dyspnea and episodes of low blood pressure. Can you tell me more about when your symptoms of shortness of breath and hypotension first began and if anything assessms to make them better or worse?

remedi_labels.value: Hello, thank you for coming in today.
when your symptoms of shortness of breath and hypotension first began
if anything seems to make them better or worse

remedi_style_dialogue_annotations.utterance_text: Well, um… thank you for seeing me. I guess my main concern is this shortness of breath—it just feels like I can’t catch my breath, and it’s gotten worse lately. I’ve also noticed my blood pressure’s been really low, at least that’s what they told me. And, actually, my back’s been hurting a lot too. I’m just… I’m pretty worried about all of this.

I can understand why you’re experiencing anxious—shortness of breath and low blood pressure can be very unsettling symptoms. You mentioned your dyspnea has worsened recently; can you describe if it comes on suddenly or gradually, and whether it’s constant or occurs at certain times, such as when lying down or with activity?

remedi_labels.value: occurs when lying down or with activity

remedi_style_dialogue_annotations.utterance_text: Well, um… the shortness of breath kind of came on gradually, I think. It’s been getting worse over the past few days. Now it feels pretty constant, even when I’m just lying down. I get really anxious because I just can’t seem to catch my breath.

remedi_labels.value: worsening over the past few days
constant shortness of breath even at rest

remedi_style_dialogue_annotations.utterance_text: I can understand why you’d be worried—experiencing short of breath and noticing your blood pressure is very low can be quite distressing. To help me with my assessment, can you tell me if you’ve noticed any swelling in your legs, chest discomfort, or changes in your urine output along with these symptoms?

Let me think… Well, I haven’t really noticed much swelling in my legs, but I do feel kind of puffy all over, especially in my belly. I haven’t had any real chest discomfort, just this back pain that’s been bothering me. As for my urine, I think I’m making less than usual—maybe not going as often. 

And, um, they told me my blood pressure’s been really low—like systolic in the 40s? My heart’s been racing too, up to the 140s sometimes. That’s part of why I’m so anxious. Should I be worried about that?

remedi_labels.value: puffy all over, especially in belly
not going as often to urinate
Should I be worried about that?

remedi_style_dialogue_annotations.utterance_text: I can absolutely understand why you’re experiencing anxious—experiencing persistent dyspnea, severe hypotension, and a rapid heart rate would be very concerning for anyone. Given your symptoms and the fact that your abdomen feels more distended, have you noticed any nausea, vomiting, or changes in your bowel movements that might help us further assess your current condition?

Um… actually, now that you mention it, I have felt kind of nauseous, but I haven’t really vomited. My bowel movements have slowed down a lot—almost like I’m constipated. My abdomen just feels really tight and uncomfortable, and it’s definitely more distended than usual.

They also mentioned something about my potassium being high—hyperkalemia, I think? And lactic acidosis… my bicarbonate was low, around 18 or 19, and the ABG showed a pH of 7.17. I’m just… I’m really worried because all these numbers sound bad. Is this something serious?

I can understand why you’d be worried—your symptoms and these laboratory findings are understandably concerning. Given your persistent dyspnea and severe hypotension, have you noticed any changes in your mental status, such as confusion, drowsiness, or difficulty staying alert, that might help us further assess the severity of your condition?

Well… I guess I have felt a bit more drowsy and kind of out of it lately, especially since all this started getting worse. Sometimes it’s hard to stay fully alert, and I get confused about what day it is. 

Also, my abdomen keeps getting bigger—like, the girth is definitely increasing. They mentioned something about my peak airway pressures going up to 40, which I think is making it even harder to breathe. I’m just really anxious about all these changes. Should I be worried about the abdominal distension and the airway pressures too?

remedi_labels.value: confusion about what day it is
peak airway pressures going up to 40
concern about abdominal distension and airway pressures

remedi_style_dialogue_annotations.utterance_text: I can understand why you’d be worried about these symptoms, especially with the increasing abdominal distension and difficulty breathing. To help with my assessment, have you noticed any changes in your ability to move your legs or any numbness or tingling, which could suggest that the abdominal distension is affecting your circulation or nerves?

remedi_labels.value: changes in ability to move legs

remedi_style_dialogue_annotations.utterance_text:
Well, um… since symptoms got worse, I actually ended up being intubated and sedated, so it’s been hard to really notice changes in my legs or anything like that. Before that, I didn’t really feel numbness or tingling, but honestly, it’s all kind of a blur now. 

They did mention I have a protuberant ventral hernia and that my abdomen is really distended. I overheard someone say my bowel sounds were hypoactive, too. I’m just worried because everything seems to be getting worse—my breathing, the abdominal distension, and now all these numbers like the high potassium and lactic acidosis. 

Is this something that can be fixed? Should I be worried about all these complications?

remedi_labels.value: no numbness or tingling before intubation
Is this something that can be fixed?
Should I be worried about all these complications?

remedi_style_dialogue_annotations.utterance_text: I can absolutely understand why you’re experiencing anxious given the severity and progression of your symptoms. To further guide my assessment, have you experienced any chest pain, palpitations, or episodes of syncope in association with your dyspnea and hypotension?

Thank you for explaining everything and for asking all these questions. Um, I haven’t really had chest pain, but my heart has definitely been racing—a lot of palpitations, especially when my blood pressure drops. I haven’t passed out completely, but I’ve felt really lightheaded, almost like I might faint sometimes.

Actually, they told me I have right renal arterial bleeding and some renal insufficiency. There were multiple foci of active extravasation in the right renal artery branches, and they mentioned possible pseudoaneurysms. I’m not sure what all that means, but it sounds pretty serious. 

With all these symptoms—like the uncontrolled hypertension before, now the hypotension, the heart rate, the kidney symptoms—I’m just really anxious. Is there a way to get this under control? Should I be worried about permanent damage?

remedi_labels.value: Thank you for explaining everything and for asking all these questions.
heart racing, a lot of palpitations
lightheaded, almost like I might faint
multiple foci of active extravasation in the right renal artery branches
Is there a way to get this under control?
Should I be worried about permanent damage?

remedi_style_dialogue_annotations.utterance_text: I can understand why you’d be anxious, especially with your symptoms of persistent dyspnea and severe hypotension. To help with my assessment, have you noticed any changes in your oxygenation status, such as increased need for supplemental oxygen or worsening hypoxemia, since your abdominal distension and other symptoms have progressed?

Yes, actually… my oxygenation status has definitely gotten worse. I’m on a lot more supplemental oxygen now, and even with that, my numbers have been low. I heard someone say my PaO2 was only 46 even though I was on 100% FiO2 and PEEP of 15. That really worries me. 

They also mentioned something about multiple foci of active extravasation in my right renal artery branches, and possible foci of contained extravasation or pseudoaneurysms. I don’t fully understand what all that means, but it sounds serious. 

With all these changes—my worsening hypoxemia, the abdominal distension, and the bleeding in my kidney—I’m just really anxious. Is there anything that can be done to turn this around? Should I be worried about long-term complications?

remedi_labels.value: low oxygen saturation despite supplemental oxygen
multiple foci of active extravasation in right renal artery branches
possible foci of contained extravasation or pseudoaneurysms
Is there anything that can be done to turn this around?
Should I be worried about long-term complications?

remedi_style_dialogue_annotations.utterance_text: I can absolutely understand why you’re experiencing anxious, given your persistent dyspnea, severe hypotension, worsening abdominal distension, and the concerning laboratory findings such as elevated lactate and acidosis. Based on your symptoms and recent examination findings, I’d like to clarify—have you experienced any sudden changes in your level of consciousness or difficulty responding to those around you, which could help us further assess the severity of your current condition?

remedi_labels.value: sudden changes in level of consciousness
difficulty responding to those around you

remedi_style_dialogue_annotations.utterance_text:
Well, um… yes, I have noticed some changes. There have been times when I felt really out of it, almost like I was drifting in and out or just couldn’t focus on what people were saying. It’s hard to remember everything, but I know there were moments where I just wasn’t as responsive as usual. I think it’s gotten worse as my symptoms have progressed.

Also, they mentioned something about abnormal renal contrast withholding with delayed clearance—so my kidneys aren’t clearing symptoms out the way they should. Before all this, I had symptoms with uncontrolled hypertension, but now my blood pressure is extremely low. 

With the elevated lactate, worsening acidosis, and everything else going on, I’m just really worried. Is this all connected? And is there anything that can be done to help my kidneys and get my blood pressure and oxygenation back to normal? Should I be worried about permanent damage from all these complications?

remedi_labels.value: felt really out of it, drifting in and out, couldn’t focus, not as responsive
abnormal renal contrast withholding with delayed clearance
kidneys aren’t clearing symptoms out the way they should
Is there anything that can be done to help my kidneys and get my blood pressure and oxygenation back to normal?
Should I be worried about permanent damage from all these complications?

remedi_style_dialogue_annotations.utterance_text: I can understand why you’d be worried about these symptoms, especially given your persistent dyspnea, severe hypotension, worsening abdominal distension, and the laboratory findings of elevated lactate and acidosis. Based on your clinical presentation and recent examination, it appears your condition may be related to ongoing bleeding and possible abdominal compartment syndrome, which can severely affect organ function. To further guide my assessment, have you experienced any changes in your urine output or noticed if it has stopped completely, which would help us evaluate the extent of your renal insufficiency?

Yes, actually… my urine output has really decreased a lot. I think it’s almost stopped at times, which is worrying me. Before, I was going less often, but now it seems like hardly anything is coming out. I know you mentioned renal insufficiency, and I’m concerned that this could be making everything worse.

They also said something about diastolic congestive heart failure exacerbation, and my blood pressure has been extremely low—systolic BPs in the 40s. I’m just so anxious because it feels like everything is spiraling: the dyspnea, the hypotension, the abdominal distension, and now barely any urine.

Is all of this connected to the abdominal compartment syndrome and the ongoing bleeding? And with my heart failure history, should I be worried about permanent organ damage? Is there anything that can be done to turn this around?

remedi_labels.value: anything that can be done to turn this around

remedi_style_dialogue_annotations.utterance_text: I can understand why you’d be worried—your symptoms of persistent dyspnea, severe hypotension, marked abdominal distension, decreased urine output, and worsening laboratory findings such as elevated lactate and acidosis are all very concerning and suggest that your organs are under significant stress, likely related to abdominal compartment syndrome from ongoing intra-abdominal bleeding. Based on this assessment, have you experienced any new or worsening pain, particularly in your abdomen or back, that could help us further evaluate the progression of your condition?

remedi_labels.value: new or worsening pain in abdomen or back

remedi_style_dialogue_annotations.utterance_text:
Yes, actually… the pain in my back has definitely gotten worse, and my abdomen feels really tight and uncomfortable—almost like it’s stretching from the inside. It’s a lot more than before, and sometimes it’s hard to tell if it’s the back or the belly that pains more. I also heard someone mention “flash pulmonary edema,” and I think that’s part of why my breathing got so much worse so quickly.

My blood pressure keeps dropping, too—it seems like every time they examination, it’s even lower. I’m just really anxious because it feels like everything is getting worse all at once: the pain, the shortness of breath, the abdominal distension, and now barely any urine output.

Is this all from the abdominal compartment syndrome and the bleeding? And with symptoms like the flash pulmonary edema and my blood pressure decreasing, is there still a chance to turn this around? Should I be worried about permanent damage to my organs?

I can completely understand why you’re experiencing anxious—your symptoms of worsening dyspnea, severe hypotension, increasing abdominal distension, decreased urine output, and now significant pain are all very concerning and suggest your organs are under significant stress, likely due to abdominal compartment syndrome from ongoing intra-abdominal bleeding. Based on my assessment, urgent intervention is needed to relieve the abdominal pressure, control the bleeding, and support your organ function; this may involve surgical decompression and close monitoring in the intensive care unit. Have you been informed about any plans for surgical intervention or additional procedures to address the abdominal compartment syndrome and ongoing hemorrhage?

remedi_labels.value: abdominal compartment syndrome from ongoing intra-abdominal bleeding
worsening dyspnea, severe hypotension, increasing abdominal distension, decreased urine output, significant pain
urgent intervention to relieve abdominal pressure, control bleeding, support organ function; may involve surgical decompression and ICU monitoring
plans for surgical intervention or additional procedures to address abdominal compartment syndrome and ongoing hemorrhage

remedi_style_dialogue_annotations.utterance_text:
Thank you for explaining everything so clearly. I appreciate you being honest with me. Um, yes, I did hear the team mention something about possibly needing surgery to relieve the abdominal pressure and control the bleeding. They said it might be something called surgical decompression, and that I’d need to be in the intensive care unit for close monitoring.

I’m honestly really anxious about all of this. My lactate levels have been rising—from 5 to 7, I think—and they keep saying my acidosis is getting worse. I know those are bad signs, right? Is there a good chance that surgery can help turn symptoms around, or should I be worried about permanent damage to my organs? And, um, what are the risks with a procedure like this, given all my other medical symptoms?

remedi_labels.value: possibly needing surgery to relieve the abdominal pressure and control the bleeding
intensive care unit for close monitoring
lactate levels have been rising—from 5 to 7
Is there a good chance that surgery can help turn symptoms around?
should I be worried about permanent damage to my organs?

remedi_style_dialogue_annotations.utterance_text: I can absolutely understand why you’re experiencing anxious—your symptoms, including worsening dyspnea, severe hypotension, increasing abdominal distension, and rising lactate and acidosis, are very serious and understandably concerning. Surgical decompression and control of intra-abdominal bleeding are often critical interventions in cases like yours to relieve abdominal compartment syndrome and help restore organ function, though risks are higher given your medical history and current instability. Before proceeding, has the surgical team discussed the potential benefits and risks of the intervention with you or your family, and have they explained what to expect during the perioperative period?

remedi_labels.value: surgical decompression and control of intra-abdominal bleeding
has the surgical team discussed the potential benefits and risks of the intervention with you or your family
have they explained what to expect during the perioperative period

remedi_style_dialogue_annotations.utterance_text:
Thank you for explaining all of that. I really appreciate how thorough you’re being—it helps me feel a little more at ease, even though I’m still very anxious. The surgical team did come by and talked to me and my family about the situation. They explained that surgical decompression is pretty urgent because my abdomen is persistently distended and they measured my bladder pressures in the 20s, which I guess is really high. They said that’s a sign of abdominal compartment syndrome and that it’s putting a lot of stress on my organs.

They did go over some of the risks—like bleeding, infection, and the fact that my heart and kidneys are already under a lot of strain because of my other medical symptoms. I understand that the surgery could help relieve the pressure and maybe improve my organ function, but I’m worried about what could go wrong, especially since my blood pressure is so low and my labs keep getting worse.

Could you maybe explain a bit more about what happens during surgical decompression? And with my high bladder pressures and everything else going on, is there a good chance my organs will recover if the surgery goes well? Or should I be worried about permanent damage?

remedi_labels.value: organs under a lot of stress
heart and kidneys already under strain
chance of organ recovery if surgery goes well

remedi_style_dialogue_annotations.utterance_text: I can completely understand why you’re anxious—facing severe symptoms and the possibility of surgery is understandably overwhelming. Based on your examination findings, high bladder pressures, and laboratory clinical findings showing rising lactate and worsening acidosis, urgent surgical decompression is often necessary to relieve abdominal compartment syndrome and restore blood flow to your organs. While there are risks given your medical history and current instability, timely intervention can sometimes prevent permanent organ damage and improve your chances of recovery. Before we proceed, have you or your family had a chance to discuss your goals of care and preferences for treatment with the medical team, in case your condition changes rapidly during or after the procedure?

remedi_labels.value: laboratory clinical findings showing rising lactate and worsening acidosis
restore blood flow to your organs
timely intervention can sometimes prevent permanent organ damage and improve your chances of recovery
discuss your goals of care and preferences for treatment with the medical team

remedi_style_dialogue_annotations.utterance_text:
Thank you for being so open with me—I really do appreciate it. My family and I have started to talk about goals of care, but honestly, it’s all been happening so fast that I’m not sure we’ve had a chance to cover everything in detail. I know symptoms are serious—my oxygenation status has gotten a lot worse, with a PaO2 of only 46 even though I’m on 100% FiO2 and PEEP of 15. And I heard the team say I have profound anion gap metabolic acidosis, which I understand means my body is really struggling.

I want to do everything reasonable to give me a chance to recover, but I also don’t want to suffer if symptoms get too far gone. I’m just worried—should I be preparing for the possibility that my organs might not recover, even with surgical decompression? And if symptoms change quickly, what should my family and I be thinking about or deciding ahead of time?

remedi_style_dialogue_annotations.utterance_text: I can understand why you’d be worried—your symptoms, laboratory findings, and the rapid progression of your condition are understandably distressing. Based on my assessment, your profound hypoxemia, severe metabolic acidosis, and high lactate levels indicate that your organs are under significant stress, and urgent surgical decompression remains the best chance to restore organ function and improve your oxygenation. Given the seriousness of your condition, have you and your family had an opportunity to discuss your preferences regarding advanced life support measures, such as prolonged mechanical ventilation or resuscitation, should your symptoms worsen during or after the procedure?

remedi_labels.value: preferences regarding advanced life support measures (mechanical ventilation, resuscitation)

remedi_style_dialogue_annotations.utterance_text:
Thank you for being so honest with me. I know this is a really serious condition, and I appreciate you taking the time to explain everything. My family and I have started to talk about symptoms like advanced life support and resuscitation, but, um… I guess we haven’t made any final decisions yet. It’s all just happening so quickly, and it’s a lot to process.

I understand that with my profound hypoxemia, severe metabolic acidosis, and high lactate levels, my organs are under a lot of stress. I want to give myself the best chance to recover, so I’m open to symptoms like mechanical ventilation if it could help me get through this. But I also don’t want to be kept alive if there’s no real hope for recovery or if I’d be suffering without a good quality of life.

Is there any way to know how likely it is that my organs will recover if the surgical decompression works? And if symptoms don’t go well, what would you recommend in terms of resuscitation or life support? I just want to make sure my family and I are making the right choices.

remedi_labels.value: Thank you for being so honest with me. I know this is a really serious condition, and I appreciate you taking the time to explain everything.
organs are under a lot of stress
likelihood of organ recovery if surgical decompression works
recommendation for resuscitation or life support if symptoms don’t go well

remedi_style_dialogue_annotations.utterance_text:
I appreciate your openness and the thoughtful way you’re approaching these very difficult decisions. Based on your symptoms—persistent dyspnea, severe hypotension, profound hypoxemia, rising lactate, and worsening metabolic acidosis—my assessment is that your organs are under significant stress from abdominal compartment syndrome and ongoing bleeding. Surgical decompression offers the best chance to reverse organ dysfunction, but given your current laboratory findings and medical history, there remains a risk of permanent organ damage even with intervention. 

As we move forward, would you like the care team to continue all aggressive life-sustaining treatments, including resuscitation and prolonged mechanical ventilation, if your symptoms worsen during or after surgery, or would you prefer to set specific limits based on your goals for quality of life?

remedi_labels.value: risk of permanent organ damage even with intervention
aggressive life-sustaining treatments including resuscitation and prolonged mechanical ventilation
set specific limits based on goals for quality of life

remedi_style_dialogue_annotations.utterance_text:
Thank you for being so clear and compassionate with me—I really do appreciate it. Um, this is a lot to take in, but I want to be honest. I do want to give myself a real chance at recovery, so I’m okay with aggressive life-sustaining treatments like mechanical ventilation and resuscitation, at least for now, especially if there’s a chance my organs could recover after the surgical decompression.

But, um… if it turns out during or after surgery that my organs aren’t recovering, or if I end up needing prolonged life support with no real hope of getting back to a quality of life I’d find acceptable, I wouldn’t want to keep going with everything just for the sake of it. I’d rather focus on comfort if symptoms look hopeless.

Is it possible to try everything for now and then re-evaluate based on how I do after surgery? And, if symptoms don’t improve, can my family and I talk with you and the team again about changing the plan? I just want to make sure I have a say in what happens, and that my family understands what’s going on.
